docs.snippet: LEAD: Poor Homer Simpson. He's constantly broke. Last Christmas, when his bonus didn't materialize at the nuclear plant where he's a safety inspector, and when the Christmas savings went to get a tattoo removed from his puckish son, Bart, he was r...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Poor Homer Simpson. He's constantly broke. Last Christmas, when his bonus didn't materialize at the nuclear plant where he's a safety inspector, and when the Christmas savings went to get a tattoo removed from his puckish son, Bart, he was reduced to trying to scrounge up money for gifts by gambling his last $13 at the dog track.

headline.main: Cashing in on a Hot New Brand Name

docs.snippet: News Digital Media, the online publishing arm of the News Corporation's Fox Network, has joined the fray of companies offering free Internet service. But unlike other companies, which provide access through shopping sites and search engines, News ...
docs.lead_paragraph: News Digital Media, the online publishing arm of the News Corporation's Fox Network, has joined the fray of companies offering free Internet service. But unlike other companies, which provide access through shopping sites and search engines, News Digital uses a fan club. Fans of Bart Simpson and family can now sign up for free e-mail and Internet access www.Simpsons.com, a new World Wide Web site whose debut marks the 10th anniversary of the animated sitcom.
docs.abstract: News Digital Media, online publishing arm of News Corp's Fox Network, will provide free Internet access through Bart Simpson fan club; www.simpsons.com, new World Wide Web site, makes its debut on 10th anniversary of animated sitcom; photo (M)

docs.snippet: Homer Simpson, the dunderheaded father on ''The Simpsons,'' is renowned for his stupidity. Stephen Hawking, the Cambridge University physicist, is renowned for his brains. On Sunday night they met, fictionally speaking, when Dr. Hawking was a gues...
docs.lead_paragraph: Homer Simpson, the dunderheaded father on ''The Simpsons,'' is renowned for his stupidity. Stephen Hawking, the Cambridge University physicist, is renowned for his brains. On Sunday night they met, fictionally speaking, when Dr. Hawking was a guest character on the popular animated sitcom. Dr. Hawking, who is nearly paralyzed and voiceless from the effects of the degenerative muscular disorder known as Lou Gehrig's disease, not only agreed to being written into the episode but recorded his own lines as other voiceover guest stars do. His ''voice'' is expressed by a computerized synthesizer after he types what he wants to say.
docs.abstract: Stephen Hawking, Cambridge University physicist, agrees to appear as guest character on episode of The Simpsons (S)

headline.main: TV Notes; Homer Meets Dr. Hawking

docs.snippet: It was a standing-room-only crowd at one of the hottest free shows around and the audience was chortling with anticipation even before it began. Then the laughs broke out as Marge began whining about Homer's misguided Internet venture, Bart caused...
docs.lead_paragraph: It was a standing-room-only crowd at one of the hottest free shows around and the audience was chortling with anticipation even before it began. Then the laughs broke out as Marge began whining about Homer's misguided Internet venture, Bart caused his school bus to career off a bridge and Noah asked God whether he needed to include stink beetles on his ark. The Simpsons were up to their usual high jinks, and the theater was a nondescript conference room on the 20th Century Fox studio lot here, where the writers and actors who provide the hit animated show's voices had assembled for a Thursday morning rehearsal. It was a jarring sight for anyone who knows the characters only as lovable cartoons with bad overbites.
docs.abstract: Interview with Dan Castellaneta, who is voice of Homer Simpson, cartoon character on The Simpsons TV program; photo (M)

docs.snippet: At first glance, it would appear to be a merger of the sacred and profane.     Rupert Murdoch -- the man whose Fox Network brought to television the risque  ''Married . . . With Children,'' the nihilistic series ''The Simpsons'' and the violent ch...
docs.lead_paragraph: At first glance, it would appear to be a merger of the sacred and profane. Rupert Murdoch -- the man whose Fox Network brought to television the risque ''Married . . . With Children,'' the nihilistic series ''The Simpsons'' and the violent children's program ''Mighty Morphin Power Rangers'' -- agreed yesterday to pay $1.9 billion to acquire the cable channel controlled by Pat Robertson, the religious-right purveyor of ''The 700 Club'' Christian talk show, family-oriented movies and reruns of such wholesome programming as ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show.''
docs.abstract: Rupert Mudoch's News Corp agrees to pay $1.9 billion to acquire Family Channel, cable channel controlled by Pat Robertson, religious-right purveyor of The 700 Club Christian talk show, family-oriented movies and reruns of wholesome programming; analysts say whatever Murdoch's plans for spicing up Robertson's Family Channel, he must take care not to totally alienate viewership that has turned the operation into nation's ninth-largest cable network, reaching 67 million homes; Murdoch, whose Fox Kids Worldwide Inc unit of News Corp is acquiring Robertson-controlled holding company, International Family Entertainment Inc, is intent on expanding into cable programming and vying with other family-oriented programmers; table (L)

headline.main: Murdoch Set To Buy Family Cable Concern

docs.snippet: There are literary agents and there are secret agents -- and sometimes there is even a literary secret agent like the one Daniel Edelman met during his first days in London as the latest American to take charge of the venerable British literary ag...
docs.lead_paragraph: There are literary agents and there are secret agents -- and sometimes there is even a literary secret agent like the one Daniel Edelman met during his first days in London as the latest American to take charge of the venerable British literary agency Curtis Brown. Or at least that's how Mr. Edelman now sees it. The senior Curtis Brown staffer who took him to lunch shortly after he was recruited from New York two years ago filled him with tales of subterranean alliances, hidden motivations and personal agendas, information the "mole" obviously thought would be valuable for the new Yank in London town.

docs.snippet: Strippers work three shifts at the Palomino Club: the 5, the 8 and the 10 p.m.     New girls tend to work the 5, which means they sometimes sit around an empty club for hours, playing video games, buying themselves $11 whiskeys or $8 rum and Cokes...
docs.lead_paragraph: Strippers work three shifts at the Palomino Club: the 5, the 8 and the 10 p.m. New girls tend to work the 5, which means they sometimes sit around an empty club for hours, playing video games, buying themselves $11 whiskeys or $8 rum and Cokes, clicking up to the stage in high heels for a two-song show and getting naked for nobody but the D.J., a few other lonely strippers and their own reflections on the mirrored walls.
docs.abstract: Fourth article in series American Dreamers: The Lure of Las Vegas interviews stripper known as Trixie on her life working in Palomino Club; photos; Trixie, 32, whose real name is Stephanie Vowell, is small-town Midwesterner who is one of many thousands who flock to gambling mecca, in hopes of earning money as springboard to something better (M)

headline.main: A Life as a Live! Nude! Girl! Has a Few Strings Attached
